description:
Hi,

As I was working on the PA1 today, I ran into some trouble. When I run my code through the Python shell, everything works out well and gives me the same output that the assignment suggests. However, when I submitted the assignment to Gradescope, it says that my code has failed three tests, and gives me this message: 

Test Failed: 'float' object is not callable
I am unsure of how to revolve this error, as my code appeared to work on my end. Any help would be greatly appreciated.

pa1.py

Thank you,

Ava DeLuca
A18123567

history.description:
Hi Ava,

You need to have all of the code that you write for the PA in a function called ounces_to_grams, which is covered in next Monday's lecture.

If you want to get a head start, here is the relevant pre-lecture.

Hope this helps. Please follow-up if you have any other questions/issues.

James

description: Is the star point section at the bottom of PA1 going to be extra credit?

history.description: I'm not sure what you're referring to. There are no star points or extra credit sections in PA 1.

description:
In the "Full Program using Functions" video, the code ended with:
print("distance in miles" + str(d_mi))

In PA1, we're prompted to end the code with:
print("Weight in grams = ", weight_in_g)

Does "," in print translate to listing the parameters one after each other? When do we know when to use "+" or ","?

history.description:
When you use a + in the print function, you can only combine two strings together. 

On the other hand, using a , is more convenient since it handles type conversion for you. (i.e. you can print out a string and an integer together without the need to convert the integer to a string) In addition, the , adds an extra space for you in the output so you don't need to have the space within the string.

You can honestly use either, just take into account what you want to print using what I mentioned above ^

description:
Before I submitted my PA1, I tested it to make sure it worked, and it returned a positive result.  However, when I submitted it, Gradescope said it failed tests 1.1.1, 1.1.2, and 1.1.3.  It said that my float object was not callable.  I was wondering how these failed tests will impact my grade.

Thank you!

history.description: Always include instructors, not just me, in a private post.

description: Is the autograder score for our PA1 going to be our final score? Because the autograder keeps saying that the tests are failing, but when I run the tests on my laptop it works just fine.

history.description:
I'm not sure whether the way you're running the tests on your laptop matches the way it's done by the autograder, but I'd recommend to pay attention to the error output you're getting on Gradescope and try to adjust your code accordingly.

As a hint, make sure that you read the PA instructions thoroughly and are implementing the code using functions that match the provided descriptions (e.g. identical name, parameter(s), return type).
I'm having the same issue where my tests are failing on gradescope, however, they ran accordingly on IDLE.

follow_up.description:
A possible reason why you are experiencing this mismatch between your Autograder output and IDLE output may be due to function names. Please make sure that the name of the function you defined in your python file matches the name described in the PA1 instructions, "ounces_to_grams", otherwise the Autograder's tests will likely fail. 

If this is not the case, please ensure that your code works for the input types specified in the PA instructions, and that the format of the code is in line with the format described in the PA instructions. Also, the Autograder's error messages may provide insight as to what the issue may be. 

Additionally, tutor office hours are a great resource, so if you are ever encountering issues like this you are more than welcome to stop by office hours at autograder.ucsd.edu and us tutors can provide some guidance! 

Thank you for your inquiry, and feel free to follow up with additional questions :-)

description: Hi guys! On PA1, what does it mean or what is it asking when it says to write known bugs or issues with the code? Does this mean to describe any errors encountered during the write up of the code or to run the code in autograder first? Thank you!

history.description: Hi, documenting bugs or issues requires you to evaluate the code you've written and identify areas that might need improvement. While potentially failing an autograder test might be an issue, we encourage you to try and understand why that might be happening and identify the root of the problem in your code, if any.
If our code runs smoothly, do we leave this section of PA1 empty?

follow_up.description:
That's great! If you are not experiencing any you can write that your code ran smoothly in the section. You can also add info on what input types would not work/may cause errors for your function, or any other constraints the program has that may not necessarily be bugs. 

Thanks!

description: is there anything that we can use to help us with the PA1 write-up? I am having a hard time even with the doc with its instructions, even writing the code properly.

history.description:
Yes! The best resource available to you are Office Hours. Today, the remaining hours are from now until 5:30PM and from 7:30-9:30PM. The tutors are happy to help you out, and I'm sure you will find them helpful. You can make a ticket to receive help on autograder.ucsd.edu :-)

Additionally, there are some resources from the lab slides that may help with setting up the right files and running the python module, see below:
* Windows: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1LtJer4Ak3inzub5wOYVow9GBS-VXIilX/view* Mac: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1epsV-jlz_kUo1sh7p-Ykey0JPhDzt6qH/view?usp=sharing

Thanks for your inquiry and good luck!

Of course, so to rephrase, evaluate what the values for names1[0] and names1[1] are in code snippet A, and then do the same for code snippet B. Then, compare your results for these values between code snippets and explain whether and why there is or is not a difference between the values. 

Hope this helps! Good luck~

post_title: PA2 code not running with gradescope
description:
Dear TAs,

I submitted my PA2 and received some errors that I don't understand:

Test Failed: Failed to import test module: test_simple
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/unittest/loader.py", line 436, in _find_test_path
    module = self._get_module_from_name(name)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/unittest/loader.py", line 377, in _get_module_from_name
    __import__(name)
  File "/autograder/source/tests/test_simple.py", line 7, in <module>
    from pa2 import *
  File "/autograder/source/pa2.py", line 23
    return [sandwich[0],sandwich[-1]]
                                     ^
IndentationError: unindent does not match any outer indentation level
I wonder if you can help me with debugging the code, which is running fine with IDIE:



def bill_calculator(units):






    if units<0:






        return "Invalid Input!"






    if units<=5:






        cost = 0.5






    elif units>5 and units<50:






        cost = 0.75






    elif units>=50:






        cost = 1






    else:






        return "Invalid Input!"






    total_bill= units * cost






    return total_bill












def get_bread_list(sandwich):






   if len(sandwich) <2:






        return []






    return [sandwich[0],sandwich[-1]]






def get_filling_list(sandwich):






    if len(sandwich) <= 2:






        return []






    return sandwich[1:-1]


Thank you so much of your help!

history.description: You just have an extra space on 5th line from the bottom. The r doesn't line up with the i.

description:
Hi instructors,

Me and my partner have done the PA2 on time but only my partner submitted the code and write-up on gradescope with my name on it. Do I also need to submit the assignment in order to get grade for it?

Thanks

history.description:
They need to add you to their Gradescope submission.

There should be something that looks like this on the top right-hand-side of the submission:
Thank you so much! Will my PAs count as late assignment if I tell my partner add me to the submission at this time?

follow_up.description:
If the original submission your partner made was on time, then it won't be late. 

Here is the course policy on late submissions:
"There is no penalty for resubmissions, you can still earn full credit. We will take the highest score between your original submission and your late/resubmission.

The Late/Resubmit process also applies if your submission is late. You should strive to complete each PA before it’s posted deadline as the PAs are practice for the exams. You will also receive earlier feedback and an extra grading attempt if you submit before the original deadline.

For those assignments near the end of the quarter, the deadline for all late/resubmissions will be Friday of Week 10 at 8am. After the automatic 24-hour extenstion, we will not accept any submissions after that time, for any reason."

description: Will there be a late/resubmit assignment that can be taken instead of the original for a grade for every PA like there were for PA1 and PA2?

Yes, every PA gets a Late/Resubmit submission. 

Please see the schedule on the course website for due dates.

description: Hi! Gradescope graded my pa4 part one fine when I submitted just that, but when I included my code for part two, it gave me this error message. I'm not sure what it means or how to fix it? I've included an image of the error message as well as an image of my code that caused the problem when entered. Please help!

history.description:
You have not defined 'words' anywhere in your code. When you're calling find_and_swap inside your print function 'words' should be a list. There is nothing called 'words' in your code that is passed during your function call inside the print function.

As a side note, while submitting your code to autograder, it is best to remove all function calls that you've made for testing your function. The autograder shall pass its own test inputs to your function, so you only need the function definitions while submitting to autograder.

description: I have also been running into problems with this piece of code. I fail to see where the syntax error is. Could I please get a pointer? Thank you.

history.description: Check your if condition. You are assigning ('=') instead of comparing ('==').

description:
For part 1.1 I am trying to make separate lists with exactly 3 elements in it. However my code is creating one list with all the elements. How can I make the code to make a new list with these for loops?

def make_board(non_perishable_food, fruits, vegetables):  board = []  for i in range(len(non_perishable_food)):    for j in range(len(fruits)):      for k in range(len(vegetables)):        board += [non_perishable_food[i], fruits[j], vegetables[k]]  return board
non_perishable_food = ["canned soup", "sausage", "pasta"]fruits = ["bananas", "apples"] vegetables = ["onions"] print(make_board(non_perishable_food, fruits, vegetables))

Printed result: ['canned soup', 'bananas', 'onions', 'canned soup', 'apples', 'onions', 'sausage', 'bananas', 'onions', 'sausage', 'apples', 'onions', 'pasta', 'bananas', 'onions', 'pasta', 'apples', 'onions']

history.description:
You are concatenating a list of [<element of non_perishable_food>, <element of fruits>, <element of vegetables>] to the board list.
Remember that concatenating two lists will merge the two lists into a single list - 
For example - lst1 = [1,2,3], lst2 = [4,5,6], lst1+lst2 is [1,2,3,4,5,6]

However, if you try to append your list instead of concatenate, you will be adding a list to the end of a list.
For example - lst1 = [1,2,3], lst2 = [4,5,6], lst1.append(lst2) is [1,2,3,[4,5,6]]

Append adds whatever you pass into it to the end of a list, while concatenating will combine two lists into a single resultant list.

Does this help to solve your dilemma?

description: My testComplement 1, 2, 3 are failing but I don’t know why. For test 3, my result looks the same as the expected result but the test failed. As for test 1 and 2, my result values seemed to be flipped compared to the expected, but I’ve tried to fix it and it still failed, so I'm not sure how to fix it properly.

history.description:
Hi Anita,

I'd recommend reviewing how a complement is defined in regard to the RGB values. Currently, the only cases in which a transformation is applied is if a pixel is entirely blue (0,0,255) or entirely red (255,0,0).
From the PA instructions: "This filter returns a new image where the red and blue color components of every pixel are swapped".
As a hint, think about implementing a transformation that is less reliant on if-statements and instead performs a change in the positions of component values in (R,G,B) for every pixel.

description: I didn't modify anything in the code; however when I was testing out the code, it resulted in an error.

history.description: It seems the computer ran the code; however, I don't know how it encouters an error message

description:
I have no idea why the below function gives me "Legitmate" which is a wrong output

and why the second function do gives me right output, why this happen?

history.description:
One very important thing to remember is that whenever a return statement is encountered, the function exits, whether your loop has finished or not! The key difference here is the indentation. In the first example, only the very first values for x and y will be checked, since we will encounter a return statement and exit the function no matter what. If the pixels we check are a 1, we will return "Illegitimate" and if none of those if statements are True, we return "Legitimate". This is incorrect, since we need to check ALL possible edge pixels before we can say for sure that our pool is legitimate. 

The second piece of code does this correctly, since it will only return "Legitimate" after all possible edge pixels have been checked, and no violations were found. Hope this helps!

description: Hello, I am confused on the instructions for part 3 (testing) on PA 6. On the instructions document, it says for the function test_mirror that it will test the chromascale function. I'm not sure what the chromascale function is, I thought it would be the blend function. However, I don't know why the function says test_mirror and that on the file pa6-test.py, it tells me to call the mirror function. The instructions seem to be the same for the second test function as well, where the instructions tell me to test the crop function when it is called test_add_stamp.Does the test case require me to use the blend (chromascale) function on the original cat image, then test the mirror function on that modified image? Or do I need to test the mirror function on the original cat image? Thanks in advance.

history.description:
Hi,

There seems to be a mistake on the doc. test_mirror() function should test the mirror() function you've implemented earlier and test_add_stamp() should test the add_stamp() function. We will fix the text in the writeup, sorry about the confusion. Hope this helps!

post_title: Autograder test failed for Pa5 part1.1
description: I don't think i messed anything up, function works well on my computer

history.description: Hi, the autograder expects your function to return the result (your return statement should handle returning the correct value). Looking at your code, it seems like you're not returning anything, only printing the result to the console. Hope this helps!

description: hello, i am working on complement for pa5 but im getting errors for swapping the values of rgb. ive tried to use a list to test the function and it worked fine, so it seems like when i tried it on the image it went out of range?

history.description:
In complement("images/cat.jpg"), you're running the complement function with the string "images/cat.jpg" as the input, rather than the actual image/corresponding 2D list itself.
In order to effectively use the function on an image input, first load the image as a list using the load_img(filename) function; use the resulting 2D list of tuples as the complement function input.

I would recommend starting with print statements in your code to see if things are behaving the way you expect them to behave.

Somethings to consider:
1). What is the error trying to tell you if you are getting an explicit error in the shell?
2). How is your code behaving differently from what you're expecting?
3). Are the for loops iterating over the correct ranges?
4). Are you accessing the correct indices in the 2D array?
5). For the indices that you are accessing in the 2D array, are you making the correct modifications?

description: I went to Alexis’ tutor hours and tried to fix an issue where my code would not Import CSE8AImages. We tried to solve the problem but were unable to do so. We eneded up copying the code in CSE8AImage and inserting it into my pa5 code and it worked. Does anyone know how to solve this problem? I downloaded pillow and bumpy on the terminal too, so I’m confused why I’m running into this.

history.description:
There are many things that could be contributing to this, and it is hard to say without more information. It's good that it works now, but if you would like more specific help, I would recommend going to tutor hours on autograder.

Some generic things that might have caused this:
1). CSE8AImage was not in the same folder as the file you're trying to import it in
2). There were some mis-spellings in the code
3). A recent OS update made it such that some programs aren't working as expected.

This really varies, so it's hard to say.

post_title: what does this test fail mean?
description:
For pa8, for the 1.1.1 test, it says

Test Failed: min() arg is an empty sequence
What does it mean and how to I adjust this part of my code?
My code:
blm_protest_data = get_blm_data("blm_state.csv")
def minimum_blm_protest_attendence(states):    count = []    num = 0    for state in blm_protest_data:        if state["State"] in states:            count.append(state['TotalAttendance'])    num = min(count)    return int(num) #TODO: Return the correct value
My PA8 was never graded, therefore I couldn't do the late/ resubmit. Am I missing something?

history.description:
As I said in lecture, we couldn't grade it in 2 days, so I extended the hard deadline to Saturday and didn't open the late/resubmit.

The downside of a week 9 pa release.
